item.title: Henri Bergius
item.description:
Henri Bergius

Hacker and an occasional adventurer. Author of Create.js and NoFlo. Decoupling software, one piece at a time.

item.title: The Future of the Web Is 100 Years Old
item.description:
The Future of the Web Is 100 Years Old

The Earth may not be flat, but the web certainly is. "There is no 'top' to the World-Wide Web," declared a 1992 foundational document from the World Wide Web Consortium-meaning that there is no central server or organizational authority to determine what does or does not get published.

item.title: Sailing across the Atlantic
item.description:
Sailing across the Atlantic

I had sailed on Helena once before, on a weekend trip in the Turku archipelago. But crossing the Atlantic would be a more interesting adventure. For a month this two-masted tall ship would be our home on the ocean.

item.title: Most Citizens of the Star Wars Galaxy are Probably Totally Illiterate
item.description:
Most Citizens of the Star Wars Galaxy are Probably Totally Illiterate

Not once in any movie does someone pick up a book or newspaper, magazine, literary journal, or chapbook handmade by an aspiring Jawa poet. If something is read by someone in , it's almost certainly off of a screen (and even then, maybe being translated by a droid), and it's definitely not for entertainment purposes.

item.title: The Space Doctor's Big Idea
item.description:
The Space Doctor's Big Idea

There once was a doctor with cool white hair. He was well known because he came up with some important ideas. He didn't grow the cool hair until after he was done figuring that stuff out, but by the time everyone realized how good his ideas were, he had grown the hair, so that's how everyone pictures him.

item.title: How Should We Talk to AIs?
item.description:
How Should We Talk to AIs?

Not many years ago, the idea of having a computer broadly answer questions asked in plain English seemed like science fiction. But when we released Wolfram|Alpha in 2009 one of the big surprises (not least to me!) was that we'd managed to make this actually work.

item.title: The Art of Space Photography
item.description:
The Art of Space Photography

I've been interested in space since I was about 4 years old - I still remember the first Shuttle Launch, and even still have at home the newspaper articles from that time.

item.title: Muji, the Japanese emporium of minimalist housewares, now makes houses, too
item.description:
Muji, the Japanese emporium of minimalist housewares, now makes houses, too

If you shop at Muji, the Japanese emporium of minimalist, space-saving housewares, it's probably to pick up one of its excellent water-shedding umbrellas, or maybe a few of its adorably slender travel toothbrushes. Typically, you wouldn't buy anything that couldn't fit in your backpack.

item.title: Antibiotic resistance: World on cusp of 'post-antibiotic era'
item.description:
Antibiotic resistance: World on cusp of 'post-antibiotic era'

The world is on the cusp of a "post-antibiotic era", scientists have warned after finding bacteria resistant to drugs used when all other treatments have failed. Their report, in the Lancet, identifies bacteria able to shrug off colistin in patients and livestock in China.

item.title: Is Using iOS As Your Primary OS, Masochism?
item.description:
Is Using iOS As Your Primary OS, Masochism?

Justin Williams, in The Chicken or the iPad Pro : The sad reality is there aren't enough Omnis in the ecosystem right now to make the iPad Pro a viable productivity platform for anyone but those executives, retired folks, and masochist bloggers who jump through more hoops than a circus elephant to use an iPad instead of a Mac.
